user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint64_to_str:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint64_to_str (uint64_t val,
                   char *buf,
                   size_t buf_size)
{
  char *chr;  /**< pointer to the current printed digit */
  /* The biggest printable number is 18446744073709551615 */
  uint64_t divisor = UINT64_C (10000000000000000000);
  int digit;

  chr = buf;
  digit = (int) (val / divisor);
  mhd_assert (digit < 10);

  /* Do not print leading zeros */
  while ((0 == digit) && (1 < divisor))
  {
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }

  while (0 != buf_size)
  {
    *chr = (char) ((char) digit + '0');
    chr++;
    buf_size--;
    if (1 == divisor)
      return (size_t) (chr - buf);
    val %= divisor;
    divisor /= 10;
    digit = (int) (val / divisor);
    mhd_assert (digit < 10);
  }
  return 0; /* The buffer is too small */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 forbids modifying function parameters. The fragments selected explicitly modify parameters: buf_size-- modifies the size_t parameter buf_size, and val %= divisor modifies the uint64_t parameter val. Other lines do not modify parameters and thus need not be investigated: assigning chr = buf; only copies the pointer value into a local variable (does not modify the parameter buf itself); incrementing chr (chr++) and writing to *chr modify a local pointer and the object pointed-to (allowed per the rule); casts and computes (e.g., digit = (int)(val / divisor)) only read parameters; returns using buf (chr - buf) do not modify parameters. Therefore no other fragments appear to violate Rule 17.8.
